presenter.bio: Are we moving from FNA to FNB?

slide.title: Are we moving from FNA to FNB?
slide.titleNormalized: are we moving from fna to fnb?
slide.text: Are we moving from FNA to FNB? Nonthalee Pausawasdi, MD. Faculty of Medicine Siriraj Hospital Mahidol University, Thailand

slide.title: Evolution of needle design for EUS-guided tissue acquisition (TA)
slide.titleNormalized: evolution of needle design for eus-guided tissue acquisition (ta)
slide.text: Evolution of needle design for EUS-guided tissue acquisition (TA) Early 2000s’ Now Up to 2000 Various kinds of needles Needle Tru-cut (Quick-Core) Reverse bevel (ProCore) Fork-tip (SharkCore) Franseen (Acquire) Forward bevel (ProCore) Size 19-25 G 19 G 19,22,25 G 19,22,25 G 22,25 G 20G 1st-generation 2nd-generation 3rd-generation ROSE No ROSE if adequate sample Role of ROSE? Drawback: Lack of tissue architecture Availability of ROSE

slide.title: What needs to be considered before replacing FNA with FNB?
slide.titleNormalized: what needs to be considered before replacing fna with fnb?
slide.notes: Now, I’d like to draw your attention to the currently available evidence in regard to biopsy needle. FNA with cytologic analysis has been an excellent tool for tissue diagnosis of GI lesions but its major drawback is lack of tissue architecture limiting the ability to diagnose certain conditions. To overcome this problem, biopsy needles have been developed in order to obtain core tissue. Ideally, for biopsy needle to replace FNA, it has to have at least comparable technical perfoamce, provide better tissue adequacy, better accuracy, equally safe and cost effective.
slide.notesNormalized: now, i’d like to draw your attention to the currently available evidence in regard to biopsy needle. fna with cytologic analysis has been an excellent tool for tissue diagnosis of gi lesions but its major drawback is lack of tissue architecture limiting the ability to diagnose certain conditions. to overcome this problem, biopsy needles have been developed in order to obtain core tissue. ideally, for biopsy needle to replace fna, it has to have at least comparable technical perfoamce, provide better tissue adequacy, better accuracy, equally safe and cost effective.
slide.notesHtml: Now, I’d like to draw your attention to the currently available evidence in regard to biopsy needle. FNA with cytologic analysis has been an excellent tool for tissue diagnosis of GI lesions but its major drawback is lack of tissue architecture limiting the ability to diagnose certain conditions. To overcome this problem, biopsy needles have been developed in order to obtain core tissue. Ideally, for biopsy needle to replace FNA, it has to have at least comparable technical perfoamce, provide better tissue adequacy, better accuracy, equally safe and cost effective.
slide.text: Equally good or better technical performance Better tissue adequacy/quality WITHOUT ROSE (Less time consuming) Higher diagnostic accuracy Equally Safe Cost-effective What needs to be considered before replacing FNA with FNB?

slide.title: What is the evidence comparing FNA & FNB?

slide.notes: Now, I’d like to draw your attention to the currently available evidence in regard to biopsy needle. To overcome this problem, biopsy needles have been developed in order to obtain core tissue. Ideally, for biopsy needle to replace FNA, it has to have at least comparable technical perfoamce, provide better tissue adequacy, better accuracy, equally safe and cost effective.

slide.notesHtml: Now, I’d like to draw your attention to the currently available evidence in regard to biopsy needle. FNA with cytologic analysis has been an excellent tool for tissue diagnosis of GI lesions but its major drawback is lack of tissue architecture limiting the ability to diagnose certain conditions. To overcome this problem, biopsy needles have been developed in order to obtain core tissue. Ideally, for biopsy needle to replace FNA, it has to have at least comparable technical perfoamce, provide better tissue adequacy, better accuracy, equally safe and cost effective.
slide.text: Technical performance of needle Tissue adequacy/ quality Diagnostic accuracy Safety Cost-effective Without ROSE What is the evidence comparing FNA & FNB? Yes

slide.title: 4 Meta-analysis comparing FNA vs FNB
slide.text:
4 Meta-analysis comparing FNA vs FNB Aadam AA, Amick AE, Shah JN, et al. Gastrointest Endosc. 2014;79:AB188–9. Study N (total) Lesions Compared needle & specimen type Diagnostic accuracy Other outcomes Bang, 2016 576 Various masses, LN Procore vs FNA 22,25
NSD for overall and panc mass FNB: fewer passes Oh, 2016 896 various masses, LN Procore vs FNA 22,25
NSD for overall FNB: better in panc mass & histo core Khan, 2017 1024 SEL>2cm Procore 22 vs FNA 22
NSD FNB: fewer passes Wang, 2017 921 (8RCT) Solid panc mass Procore 22 vs FNA 22
NSD FNB: better adequacy, fewer passes +13 RCTs comparing FNA vs FNB (2012-2017): Results: NSD for diagnosis, FNB offers better histology quality with fewer passes

slide.notes: It was thought that the reason for not seeing the differences had to do with small sample size. Therefore, this multicenter RCT from China was conducted.
slide.notesNormalized: it was thought that the reason for not seeing the differences had to do with small sample size. therefore, this multicenter rct from china was conducted.
slide.notesHtml: It was thought that the reason for not seeing the differences had to do with small sample size. Therefore, this multicenter RCT from China was conducted.
slide.text: Aadam AA, Amick AE, Shah JN, et al. Gastrointest Endosc. 2014;79:AB188–9. Outcomes (N=377) FNB (N=190) (procore 22) FNA (N=187) (Echotip 22) P value Overall diagnostic accuracy 91% 80% 0.0015 Pancreatic mass : Histology (N=249) 93% 82% 0.0099 Pancreatic mass : Cytology 89% 79% 0.0047 Non-pancreatic lesions similar similar NS

slide.title: Prospective assessment of the diagnostic performance of EUS-FNB (Acquire 22G) in abdominal masses (N=100) without ROSE
slide.titleNormalized: prospective assessment of the diagnostic performance of eus-fnb (acquire 22g) in abdominal masses (n=100) without rose
slide.text: CA gallbladder 1.7% Spindle cell tumor 1.7% Neuroendocrine tumor (NET) 1.7% Lymphoma 1.7% Leiomyoma 1.7% Disseminated cryptococcosis 1.7% Atypical cell 1.7% Epitheloid cell aggregation 1.7% Other (13%) Prospective assessment of the diagnostic performance of EUS-FNB (Acquire 22G) in abdominal masses (N=100) without ROSE DDW 2018

slide.title: Diagnostic Performance of EUS-FNB for solid masses (n=100)
slide.titleNormalized: diagnostic performance of eus-fnb for solid masses (n=100)
slide.notes: Overall diagnostic performance of EUS-FNB ในการวินิจฉัย solid intra-abdominal mass had a sensitivity of 88.1% (95% CI,77.1-95.1), specificity of 100% (95% CI, 2.5-100), positive predictive value (PPV) of 100% (95% CI,93.2-100), negative predictive value (NPV) of 12.5% (95% CI,0.3-52.7), the area under the receiver operating curve (AUROC) of 0.941 (95% CI,0.851-1.000) with the accuracy of 88.3%. For detection of malignancy, FNB had a sensitivity of 97.7% (95% CI,87.7-99.9), specificity of 90% (95% CI, 55.5-99.7), positive predictive value (PPV) of 97.7% (95% CI,87.7-99.9), negative predictive value (NPV) of 90% (95% CI,55.5-99.7), the area under the receiver operating curve (AUROC) of 0.938 (95% CI,0.826-1.000) with the accuracy of 96.2%.
slide.notesNormalized: overall diagnostic performance of eus-fnb ในการวินิจฉัย solid intra-abdominal mass had a sensitivity of 88.1% (95% ci,77.1-95.1), specificity of 100% (95% ci, 2.5-100), positive predictive value (ppv) of 100% (95% ci,93.2-100), negative predictive value (npv) of 12.5% (95% ci,0.3-52.7), the area under the receiver operating curve (auroc) of 0.941 (95% ci,0.851-1.000) with the accuracy of 88.3%. for detection of malignancy, fnb had a sensitivity of 97.7% (95% ci,87.7-99.9), specificity of 90% (95% ci, 55.5-99.7), positive predictive value (ppv) of 97.7% (95% ci,87.7-99.9), negative predictive value (npv) of 90% (95% ci,55.5-99.7), the area under the receiver operating curve (auroc) of 0.938 (95% ci,0.826-1.000) with the accuracy of 96.2%.
slide.notesHtml: Overall diagnostic performance of EUS-FNB ในการวินิจฉัย solid intra-abdominal mass had a sensitivity of 88.1% (95% CI,77.1-95.1), specificity of 100% (95% CI, 2.5-100), positive predictive value (PPV) of 100% (95% CI,93.2-100), negative predictive value (NPV) of 12.5% (95% CI,0.3-52.7), the area under the receiver operating curve (AUROC) of 0.941 (95% CI,0.851-1.000) with the accuracy of 88.3%. For detection of malignancy, FNB had a sensitivity of 97.7% (95% CI,87.7-99.9), specificity of 90% (95% CI, 55.5-99.7), positive predictive value (PPV) of 97.7% (95% CI,87.7-99.9), negative predictive value (NPV) of 90% (95% CI,55.5-99.7), the area under the receiver operating curve (AUROC) of 0.938 (95% CI,0.826-1.000) with the accuracy of 96.2%.
slide.text:
PPV: positive predictive value, NPV: negative predictive value, CI: confidence interval, AUROC: Area under Receiver-Operating Characteristics curve
Diagnostic Performance of EUS-FNB for solid masses (n=100)

slide.title: Current status: FNA vs FNB
slide.text:
Current status: FNA vs FNB Now 2020 onwards FNA- FNB Technical performance of needle Comparable Comparable Tissue adequacy/quality Inferior Superior Diagnostic accuracy Better in pancreatic cancer Safety Comparable
Comparable
Cost Comparable to FNB in US (other regions not known) Comparable to FNA in US (other regions not known)
Lots of on-going research (clinical trial.gov)
49 trials 34 RCTs Comparing FNA vs FNB Comparing FNB vs FNB (different kinds) ROSE vs NO ROSE Population: pancreatic ca, GIST, lymphoma, solid lesions
FNB definitely has a role in molecular profiling
FNB
